Carbon, Hydrogen, and Oxygen combined together in the molecule cellulose (C6 H10 O5) one of the most abundant natural polymers.

The natural cellular processes are what drive this production of the cellulose i.e.

6(CO2) + 5(H2O) + P.S. --> Cellulose (C6H10O5) + (2O2) + O

The cellulose is deposited in the cell walls and the excess O2 is released while the remaining O is combined with another O from a seperate or similar process.

It's important to note that:

*as we do, trees also need oxygen for cellular respiration, and without it they can't grow.
*trees, or plants, are not made mostly of "air", but carbon that is "fixed" in a organic form (from CO2 available in the air) . It's easy to think that plants are made from air because they uses air, but this is a misconception as well. Plants do extract the bulk of it's mass from components found in the air.
*Oxygen that plants provide comes from the water and not from CO2 (O-C-O), as many people think.

So, I get the general point he's making here, but to nitpick slightly: most of the mass in trees (it varies, but the internet agrees it's generally over 50%) comes from water, mostly extracted from the soil around it. The dry weight of a large tree is largely from lignin and other carbohydrates, which themselves are only partially carbon from carbon dioxide. I haven't done an analysis of the biochemical pathway to see where the oxygens in the carbohydrates comes from, but I'd bet most of them also come from water. So, most of the mass of a tree does come from water. But a good chunk does come from the air.

In this magical closed system, where a tree slowly consumes a human by using the CO2 they produce to create glucose in photosynthesis, has to have a few key things. It needs sources of air, soil, water, and light. (Yes you do actually need all of those things mentioned in the video.) Photosynthesis needs soil indirectly to function. It needs the magnesium found in the soil to create chlorophyll. It also uses other minor ionic metals that could not be found in... the air, or in light. The first process in photosynthesis uses water. It breaks a water molecule into hydrogen and oxygen (the oxygen is then removed from the plant with all due haste; as it is a deadly toxin to a later part of the process.) If the plant did not have a supply of water, the plant would be unable to complete the first part of photosynthesis, and it would die. The first part of photosynthesis also involves light. Remember that chloroplast we made from that magnesium in dirt? Well, if there wasen't any light to cause the chloroplast to give off electrons, then photosynthesis would not happen.

Trees are certainly not made of gas. The process autotrophs use to create nutrient materials is called photosynthesis. It involves taking the CO2 we breathe out, combining it with solar energy and water. With those 3 components coming together, the autotrophs create nutrient materials(chlorophyll, starch, etc.) and release oxygen, which is one of the gasses we use in the breathing process, typically the inhaling. So what I'm saying is, the heterotroph and the autotroph are in a symbiosis, with the heterotrophs exhaling CO2, which the autotrophs use to create O2. Back to the trees, that chlorophyll they create is usually stored in their plants, but unfortunately they create more than they can store in the plants so they store it inside them instead. That is a part of how trees get their mass, because there is a lot of water flowing through the stem which is necessary for the photosynthesis process to occur, and it's also the way trees get minerals and nutrient materials from the soil (Root >> Stem >> Branches >> Leaves). And that my friends is how trees get their mass! :D

So what I'm saying here is that trees, and all plants have chloroplasts and mitochondria! Which means they are actually extracting energy from organic fuel molecules in an a way that is very similar to animals, including humans- by aerobic respiration within the mitochondria!No real reciprocal metabolic harmony to speek of...
Over the larger life-cycle of any plant, from birth to death (and a little bit after death as its tissues get utilized by various detritivores) plants are carbon neutral at best, but not net carbon fixers!

You should talk about the misconception of where the oxygen we breathe in goes in our bodies and where the carbon dioxide we breathe out comes from.  It's really interesting and until biochem classes I honestly thought the oxygen we breathed in became the CO2 we breathed out, but that is exactly false.  Almost none of that oxygen becomes CO2, almost all of it becomes water, and that CO2 comes from us oxidizing sugars down from C6H12O6 to CO2 and H2O (obviously some of the carbon hydrogen and oxygen in the sugar is conserved in one go round of the TCA cycle, but after a few cycles all the carbon from the original sugar is converted to CO2).  It's truly amazing and unintuitive, and I'm sure you could surprise a few people with it :)

The more I think about this question, the more I think your conclusion is at least partially incorrect. Let's assume at least 50% of the tree is made up of cellulose. What does the tree do with the electrons? Adds them to the carbon in CO2 to make sugar. The sugar molecules link up and you get wood!

The tree is not 95% carbon dioxide.  The only thing the tree uses is the carbon part.  It takes in Carbon Dioxide, and light, converts/splits that apart into carbon and oxygen, and then gets rid of the oxygen back into the air.  It only keeps the carbon, which is solid (charcoal is carbon, and charcoal is just burnt wood, aka a tree).

CO2 enters the tree and undergoes necessary biochemical reactions which separate the C from the O2. The carbon is then used as a building block for the tree; it is no longer in the gas state. The waste product is O2, which is then expelled from the tree (lucky for us).

Ignore the other answer you were given. The answer is that plants get their CO2 through their leaves, not their roots. Leaves are covered with tiny pores called stomata, which allow air to flow into the leaf, while the cells within the leaf have air spaces between them. Gases diffuse across the cell membranes and dissolves into the water inside the cells. No actual gas bubbles get inside the cells, or this would break the water supply as described in the other video.

The water goes into the soil and absorbs the nutrients in the soil, then the roots take it up the trunk to the leaves, there it hits sunlight and CO2 and is converted into a Glucose that has absorbed the Carbon and then goes back into the tree for growth, leaving the Oxygen to expel from the leaves. that is why trees burn so well, because they absorb all of that carbon and nitrogen, also, when you heat a green branch over a flame, you can see the sugar running out of the cut end.

To answer your question, the trees are not made up of "carbon dioxide gas." As we know, CO2 is a molecule, and the trees are made primarily of the carbon atom contained in the molecule (Gas - CO2). Obviously the tree does this many MANY molecules of CO2 at a time, otherwise it would take ages to grow 1 leaf.
